questions.question:
Question 2: As part of a public outreach initiative under the National Programme for Control of Blindness 
and Visual Impairment, you are screening the population of a neighboring village. While 
preparing your report, what definition of blindness would you use?

options.a: Presenting distance visual acuity less than 3/60 in the better eye
options.b: Presenting distance visual acuity less than 1/60 in the better eye
options.c: Presenting distance visual acuity less than 6/60 in the better eye
options.d: Presenting distance visual acuity less than 2/60 in the better eye

questions.explanation:
The definition of blindness under the National Programme for Control of Blindness and Visual 
Impairment (NPCBVI) is presenting distance visual acuity of less than 3/60 in the better eye and 
limitation of the field of vision to less than 10 degrees from the center of fixation.

questions.question: Question 3: Which is the most common cause of preventable childhood blindness?
questions.explanation:
The most common cause of preventable childhood blindness is vitamin A deficiency. The most common cause of blindness (including adults), is however, cataract. 603 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 4: You have examined five patients(i-v) in the OPD this morning. Their visual acuity test results 
are as given below. Who amongst them would be described as blind as per the WHO Vision 
2020 definition? 599 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Patients iii and iv would be classified as blind. In the Vision 2020 initiative, the WHO has revised its definition of blindness. As per the new 
definition, "Blindness is defined as a presenting visual acuity of worse than 3/60 or a corresponding visual 
field loss to less than 10° in the better eye." Note: Blindness is defined for the better eye, hence option (i) is insufficient information to classify 
as blind, as information about the better eye is not given.

questions.question: Question 5: Which organization does the image given below stand for?

options.a: National Programme for Control of Blindness
options.d: National Programme for Control of Blindness and Visual Impairment

questions.explanation:
The symbol stands for National Programme for Control of Blindness and Visual Impairment 
(NPCBVI), which was previously called the National Programme for Control of Blindness.

questions.question:
Question 6: A 1-year-old child is brought to the well-baby clinic for immunization. What is the dose of 
prophylactic vitamin A to be given to her?
questions.explanation: The dose of vitamin A prophylaxis for a 1-yr-old child would be 2 lakh IU orally. Dose of oral vitamin A for prophylaxis: • Less than 6 months of age: 50,000 IU • 6–11 months of age: 1 lakh IU • 12 months and more: 2 lakh IU

questions.question:
Question 9: What is the number of primary-level vision centers proposed to be developed across the 
country as per the Vision 2020 Program?
questions.explanation:
The number of primary-level vision centers proposed as per the Vision 2020 Program is 20,000. Centers

questions.question:
Question 10: A 45-year-old Nigerian man hailing from an area endemic for river blindness presented with 
the given finding. What is the drug of choice for the treatment? 601 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The image shows sclerosing keratitis of onchocerciasis or river blindness. The drug of choice for 
the treatment of onchocerciasis is ivermectin. Ivermectin: 6 mg, single-dose, repeated every 6-12 months, according to the weight of the patient. Suramin and diethylcarbamazine (DEC) were given in the past but have been discontinued due to 
serious adverse effects.

questions.question:
Question 11: You are appointed as the regional doctor in charge of overseeing the activities under 
Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK). All of the following diseases are specifically 
covered under the purview of this program except?
questions.explanation:
Congenital glaucoma is not covered under Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK) Child health screening and early intervention services under RBSK envisages to cover 30 selected 
health conditions for screening, early detection, and free management in the age group birth to 18 
years. The eye conditions that are covered are • Vitamin A deficiency • Congenital cataract • Vision impairment • Retinopathy of prematurity 606 
Sold by @itachibot Instruments in Ophthalmology
